text:
I've just downloaded the new apache server build 2.0.36 for windows xp. I've 
installed it without errors. The service has started(successful). I've opened 
up Internet Explorer and connected to http://ipaddress and I've been referred 
to the default startup page that confirms its successfull installation/setup.

After a reboot, windows xp seems to 'unload' the apache service, or stops the 
service, it claims that its not a valid microsoft serivice. The icon in the 
tray shows that the 'service is not installed'. I'm guessing its been unloaded 
but for no appearant reason. I've uninstalled, and reinstalled the new build 
and still same problems, I have not had a previous version installed due to 
the fact that i've just reinstalled windows, sad. I have used build 2.0.35 in 
the previous installation with complete success. I could not find that build 
on apache.org for download, sad. The new build is much simplified and takes 
less time to execute with its service monitors.
creator: ddebidin@hotmail.com

text:
Look in Start ... Settings ... Control Panel ... Administrative Tools.

  Is Apache2 in the list?

  If so, look in the Event viewer (also in Administrative Tools) under the
  Applications list for the last few events, you may find an apache error
  reported there (before the service could even open the log files.)

  If not, I suspect that [although it started somehow] you either have some
  automatic system configuration/restore tools running, or that you had another
  web server running on port 80 when you attempted to install Apache.  Stop other
  web servers and reinstall Apache.

  Either way, we aught to change the installer to output error results to the
  installation log (that the awk script creates) by using the new -E errorlog
  command line option when attempting to install Apache.  This way, the user
  will be told the results of attempting to install the service for future
  troubleshooting of this sort.
creator: wrowe@apache.org
wrowe@apache.org
text:
The only problem with the -E logging idea is that -E would become an
  option of the service's config, which is not what we intended.

  The right way is probably to simply test the port for success, and hold
  the console open on errors.  Or test the port, and then try to invoke
  bin\apache -k install >> our_install_log_file, but I don't know if you
  can pipe a custom msi action.

creator: wrowe@apache.org
text:
The only answer, after considering the various headaches in launching the
  apache -k install command, is to test for the most obvious fault points in
  real_features, our MSI extension that already probes for WinSock2, etc.

  By identifying that port 80 or 8080 is in use, it could come up with an 
  alternative port.  It could finally test the selected port in a user-select
  dialog.

  This change doesn't need to wait for a specific release, just for the
  availability of someone to try hacking this fix.
*** Bug 9711 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
creator: wrowe@apache.org
wrowe@apache.org
text:
Easier to read than "Installer needs httpd-win32-msi/src/real_features 
  to test port availablity" although that is still true.
*** Bug 10275 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
creator: wrowe@apache.org

text: *** Bug 11806 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
creator: wrowe@apache.org
philip@stoev.org
text:
It appears to me that "service installation" and "server start" should be two 
independent items. Therefore, if port 80 is occupied, installing the service 
should succeed, whereas even if starting the server fails, the user will have 
the opportunity to edit httpd.conf and start the server without being forced to 
do an apache -k install manually.

creator: apache@rolfvandekrol.nl
text:
Do you have Skype installed on your computer? Yes, that matters. Skype, by
default, uses port 80 for incoming connections. You can disable this behavior
somewhere in the settings of Skype.

creator: wrowe@apache.org
text:
Resolved with Apache 2.2.

  FYI IIS is another treasure, if you configure your IIS host to 192.168.0.1
  and Apache to 192.168.0.2 explicitly, IIS still gloms onto 0.0.0.0 during
  it's startup phase.

  Anyways, the service will now install even if port is in use.
